title: The Chicago Internet Walking Tour
content: Though we interact with the Internet every day on our phones and laptops, that view only scratches the surface of a vast, hidden network often reduced to abstract notions like “the cloud.” On the Internet Walking Tour, Ingrid Burrington—author of Networks of New York—revealed Chicago’s physical infrastructure: the spray-painted street markings, manhole covers, junction boxes, cable routers and buildings that quietly power our wired world.

But the Internet isn’t just wired; it’s also wireless. With Nick Briz and Brannon Dorsey’s WiFi Data Safari app, invisible packets became visible as we peeked into building networks and observed devices “spewing out personally identifiable information into the WiFi ether for anyone to capture and use,” illustrating, as Real Life Magazine wrote, “all the data that anyone—marketers, governments, malefactors—could learn to pick up from the wi-fi radio ether.”
